stream_context.summary: Kaze brainstorms and designs the multi-phase boss fight for Raphael the Raven in Course 13. He models the tower arena, imports and loops music for the level, and discusses game design philosophy with his chat, particularly regarding difficulty and collectibles.
level: Raphael the Raven Boss Fight Arena

development_findings.summary: Kaze prioritizes creating memorable, visually impressive set-pieces for boss fights, with innovative gameplay being a secondary but still important goal.
development_findings.quote: But it being a cool set-piece is my number one priority for bosses, always.

development_findings.summary: The Raphael the Raven boss fight is planned as a multi-phase encounter where Mario is launched to a moon, fights the raven on its surface, and uses thrown items spawned by the raven's attacks to deal damage.
The project is planned to have 15 levels, approximately 180 stars, and 75 Yoshi Coins. The soundtrack currently contains 98 original songs.
development_findings.quote: There's going to be like, I think, 180 stars on top of that. So I guess content-wise, it's probably going to be pretty comparable to, or maybe more, I don't know, hard to say.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to implement planetary gravity for the moon-based boss fight and intends to seek help from someone named Arthur who has already developed code for this feature.
development_findings.quote: I'm going to ask Arthur for his planetary gravity code because he already knows what to do, I think.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identifies a bug in the Fast64 toolset where using 'material bleeding' can cause fog to remain enabled incorrectly, affecting the visuals of levels on original N64 hardware.
Kaze believes placing major collectibles like 100-coin stars on the critical path to another objective is bad design, as it forces the player into a frustrating choice.
development_findings.quote: If you put them on paths that lead to stars, you're going to walk the path, get the star, and now you have to get the coins again... Both of it is awful.

development_findings.summary: Kaze detailed the process of importing and looping streamed audio, which involves manually finding loop points in an editor and calculating the corresponding sample values for the game's audio engine.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the core of Mario 64's design is freedom, allowing players to create their own difficulty through risky, skillful maneuvers rather than the game enforcing a high difficulty level.
context_findings.quote: The point is that you're free. It's all freedom. Like if you want the game to be more difficult, do more risky jumps. You just go for it. You know, you're free in Mario 64. That's the great part.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally avoids looking at Nintendo's leaked source code (the 'Gigaleak') to prevent being influenced by or accidentally incorporating proprietary information, which he calls 'cursed knowledge'.
context_findings.quote: I never looked at the giga league actually, funnily. I wanted nothing to do with that. Just because I think that even just knowing about things in the giga league can get you in trouble. It's like the curse knowledge.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses disdain for people who enter programming solely for high salaries, believing this mentality created an unsustainable bubble in the tech industry.
context_findings.quote: I'm in this for money. I don't care about whether I'm fulfilled. I want money... That's how people treat programming for the longest time. And of course the bubble was going to burst.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions his newborn child with Zeina, discussing the division of parental duties and his inability to breastfeed.
Kaze discusses his personal fitness routine, focusing on the 'big four' lifts (bench, squat, deadlift, and weighted pull-ups), and mentions he is recovering from a recent knee injury.

biobak.summary: Biobak contributed a video concept for the Raphael the Raven boss fight, which Kaze found impressive and used as inspiration.
biobak.quote: Let me just see if I can find the video that bio back had sent me here a while ago. Yes. Video. Oh. This is what he was thinking. That's so cool.

badub.summary: Kaze praises Badub's creativity and the quality of his musical contributions to the project.
badub.quote: Badubb's music is great. The creativity he brings to the table is very, very sick.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions that his wife, Zeina, is shouldering more of the work of caring for their newborn child.
zeina.quote: Of course, Zeina has a lot more work with it than I do. I guess I can't feed the baby, I do not have boobs.

key_stories.title: Designing the Raphael the Raven Boss Fight
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a unique boss fight for Raphael the Raven. After reviewing a concept from Biobak and brainstorming with his chat, he designed a multi-phase encounter on a moon with planetary gravity, prioritizing a cool set-piece experience with innovative gameplay.
key_stories.challenge: How to design a boss fight for Raphael the Raven that is a unique, 3D experience and not just a copy of the 2D Yoshi's Island fight or a Mario Galaxy boss.
key_stories.process: Kaze started by reviewing a concept video from Biobak. He then brainstormed live with his chat, considering and discarding ideas like a hollow moon due to technical complexity. He ultimately combined the ideas of a cool moon set-piece with innovative gravity mechanics and specific attack patterns to create a full fight concept.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze developed a detailed, multi-phase boss fight concept. It begins with a dramatic cutscene, launches Mario to a moon, and involves fighting the raven on a spherical surface, dodging its attacks, and using items spawned from those attacks to damage it.
key_stories.key_quote: But it being a cool set-piece is my number one priority for bosses, always.

key_stories.title: The Philosophy of Freedom vs. Difficulty
key_stories.summary: Kaze defended his philosophy that Mario 64's core appeal is freedom, not forced difficulty. He demonstrated how players can create their own challenges in the original game by attempting risky maneuvers, a principle he is carrying into his own design.
key_stories.challenge: Justifying the design philosophy that Mario 64 is not an inherently 'easy' game and doesn't need to be made arbitrarily difficult.
key_stories.process: In response to chat comments, Kaze articulated his game design philosophy. He booted up the original Super Mario 64 and demonstrated how a player can perform difficult, risky, and faster jumps, showing that the game's challenge comes from the player's creativity and mastery of the controls.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze's design principle for the hack is to preserve the freedom of movement from the original game, allowing players to create their own challenges through skillful play rather than having difficulty forced upon them.
key_stories.key_quote: The point is that you're free. It's it's all freedom. Like if you want the game to be more difficult and do more risky jumps. Just go for it.
